shortDescription: Three-pronged spear forged by the Cyclopes, Poseidon's weapon to command seas, earthquakes, and storms
longDescription: The Trident (Greek: œÑœÅŒØŒ±ŒπŒΩŒ± triaina) is the three-pronged spear wielded by Poseidon, god of the sea. Like Zeus's thunderbolt and Hades's helm, it was forged by the Cyclopes as a gift after their liberation from Tartarus. The trident grants Poseidon complete dominion over all waters‚Äîhe can calm or raise storms, create springs by striking rock, cause earthquakes (earning him the epithet 'Earthshaker'), and command all sea creatures. The three prongs have been interpreted as symbolizing Poseidon's threefold dominion over seas, rivers, and springs, or his power over past, present, and future tides. As a symbol of marine sovereignty, the trident represents both the creative and destructive aspects of water.
powers: Ocean control, earthquake creation, storm summoning, spring creation, marine life command

firstAttestation.description: Estimated based on mythology literary tradition

worshipPractices: Divine instrument of Poseidon's sovereignty over all waters, used to command seas, create earthquakes, strike springs from stone, and demonstrate maritime authority

modernLegacy.culturalImpact: The trident became the universal symbol of marine power and appears on Greco-Roman coins, mosaics, and maritime symbols to this day. Naval powers adopted trident imagery to invoke Poseidon's favor. The trident symbol influenced Neptune's iconography in Roman culture and continues to represent oceanic authority in modern contexts, from naval insignia to corporate logos. Coastal cities treated the trident as a sacred protective emblem.

festivals.description: Athletic games held in Poseidon's honor at Corinth, with trident symbols prominent
festivals.name: Isthmian Games

festivals.description: Sailors offered sacrifices invoking Poseidon's trident for safe passage
festivals.name: Naval Sacrifices

textReferences.context: The Cyclopes forge divine weapons including the trident
Poseidon drives his chariot over the sea with his trident
Poseidon strikes the sea with his trident to create a storm against Odysseus
Poseidon's contest with Athena, striking the Acropolis with his trident
The mark of Poseidon's trident on the Acropolis

mythologyContexts.usage: Divine instrument of Poseidon's sovereignty over all waters, used to command seas, create earthquakes, strike springs from stone, and demonstrate maritime authority
mythologyContexts.symbolism: The trident represents dominion over the fluid, unpredictable realm of water‚Äîboth creative (springs, rain, fertility) and destructive (storms, earthquakes, drowning). Its three prongs suggest completeness and cosmic order applied to chaos. As Poseidon rules the sea yet desires land (competing with Athena for Athens), the trident symbolizes ambition and the tension between domains. The weapon's ability to strike water from stone (like Moses's staff) represents hidden abundance and miraculous provision.

Naval powers adopted trident imagery to invoke Poseidon's favor. The trident symbol influenced Neptune's iconography in Roman culture and continues to represent oceanic authority in modern contexts, from naval insignia to corporate logos. Coastal cities treated the trident as a sacred protective emblem.

name: Trident of Poseidon

cognates.notes: English borrowing from Greek via Latin
